The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, also known as the National Dam Safety Program Act, amends the existing program to focus on coordination and information exchange among Federal agencies for implementing dam safety guidelines. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, also known as the National Dam Safety Program Act, introduces amendments to improve dam safety in the United States. These include changes to strategic planning, duties of the Director, and the development of technical assistance materials for enhancing dam security. The Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002 introduces amendments to improve dam safety in the United States, including coordinating national efforts to enhance dam safety, redesignating subsections for implementation plans and dam safety training, and providing assistance for state dam safety programs. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Dam Safety and Security Act of 2002, including providing assistance to states for improving dam safety programs and changing terminology from "contract" to "agreement" in paragraph (3). The Director is required to establish monitoring for dam safety in the United States and advise on national dam safety policy. Voting membership in the committee is amended to include 11 voting members, with 5 selected from State dam safety officials and 1 representing the private sector. Nonvoting membership and duties are also outlined. The Director, in consultation with the Board, may invite nonvoting members like representatives from National Laboratories of the Department of Energy or dam safety experts to participate in Board meetings. The Board's duties include promoting effective dam safety programs nationwide and facilitating coordination among Federal and State dam safety agencies. The Director may establish work groups under the Board to assist in achieving dam safety goals. Travel expenses for Board members representing Federal agencies will be reimbursed by their respective agencies. The Board members will be reimbursed for travel expenses, including per diem, while away from home or regular place of business, in line with rates authorized for federal agency employees under title 5 of the United States Code. SEC. 4. RESEARCH.

Amends Section 9(a) to cooperate with the Board, develop and support information resources systems for dam safety, and guide public policy for dam safety engineering, security, and management.

SEC. 5. DAM SAFETY TRAINING.

Amends the Act to include a new section on dam safety training. SEC. 10. DAM SAFETY TRAINING. The Director will provide training for State dam safety staff and inspectors upon request. SEC. 6. REPORTS. Section 11 is amended by removing subsection (a) and everything following it until "(b) Biennial Reports.--". SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 13 of the Act is amended to increase annual amounts to $6,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2006. Allocation changes include updating references to sections and removing outdated language. Research funding is set at $1,500,000 for each fiscal year 2003 through 2006 for section 9 activities. Authorized appropriations for dam safety training and additional staff personnel for FEMA are set at $500,000 and $600,000 respectively for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2006.
